official-title.#text:
Recognizing the Sabin Vaccine Institute on
		  the 20th anniversary of its founding.

cosponsor.#text: Ms. Eddie Bernice Johnson of Texas

cosponsor.#tail:
) submitted the following resolution; which was referred to
			 the

text.#text:
applauds the Sabin Vaccine Institute on 20
			 years of success;

supports the Sabin
			 Vaccine Institute, Texas Children’s Hospital, and Baylor College of Medicine in
			 their efforts to reduce the prevalence of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) by
			 developing new vaccines, advocating for increased use of existing vaccines, and
			 expanding access to affordable medicine for the world’s poorest people;
			 and

encourages the
			 leadership and staff of the Sabin Vaccine Institute, Texas Children’s Hospital,
			 and Baylor College of Medicine to continue their commendable work on behalf of
			 those who still suffer from NTDs and vaccine-preventable diseases.

Whereas the Sabin Vaccine Institute was founded in honor
			 of the late Dr. Albert B. Sabin, a distinguished scientific figure in the
			 history of medicine and the developer of the oral live-virus polio vaccine, who
			 died on March 3, 1993;

Whereas for the past 20 years, the Sabin Vaccine Institute
			 has demonstrated noteworthy success in its mission to reduce the prevalence of
			 neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) by developing new vaccines, advocating for
			 increased use of existing vaccines, and expanding access to affordable medicine
			 for the world’s poorest people;

Whereas the Sabin Vaccine Institute and Texas Children’s
			 Hospital Center for Vaccine Development, operating in partnership with Baylor
			 College of Medicine and many collaborators worldwide, is dedicated to the
			 creation of vaccines to prevent NTDs;

Whereas the Sabin Vaccine Institute raises public
			 visibility and mobilizes the necessary funding in the pursuit of controlling
			 and eliminating the seven most common NTDs, including roundworm, hookworm,
			 whipworm, lymphatic filariais (elephantiasis), schistosomiasis (snail fever),
			 trachoma, and river blindness, which can be treated for approximately 50 cents
			 per person per year with existing medicine;

quote.#text:
reduce needless human suffering from vaccine-preventable and neglected
			 tropical diseases (NTDs) by developing new vaccines, advocating for increased
			 use of existing vaccines, and promoting expanded access to affordable medical
			 treatments

text.#text: Whereas the Sabin Vaccine Institute’s mission is to

Whereas the Sabin Vaccine Institute understands the
			 importance that healthy infants and adults have on family stabilization and
			 productive societies; and

Whereas the Sabin Vaccine Institute continues its work
			 throughout impoverished countries of the world to improve the future lives of
			 nearly 2,000,000,000 people still plagued by NTDs and vaccine-preventable
			 diseases: Now, therefore, be it
